appendix.title: A simple example package: bison
appendix.para: We checked to find a piece of software that wasn't in the packages collection, and picked GNU bison. Quite why someone would want to have bison when Berkeley yacc is already present in the tree is beyond us, but it's useful for the purposes of this exercise.

sect2.title: Makefile
sect2.programlisting:
# $NetBSD$ #
DISTNAME= bison-1.25 CATEGORIES= devel MASTER_SITES= ${MASTER_SITE_GNU}
MAINTAINER= thorpej@NetBSD.org HOMEPAGE= http://www.gnu.org/software/bison/bison.html COMMENT= GNU yacc clone
GNU_CONFIGURE= yes INFO_FILES= bison.info
.include "../../mk/bsd.pkg.mk"

sect2.title: DESCR
sect2.programlisting: GNU version of yacc. Can make re-entrant parsers, and numerous other improvements. Why you would want this when Berkeley &man.yacc.1; is part of the &os; source tree is beyond me.

sect2.title: Checking a package with pkglint
sect2.para: The NetBSD package system comes with pkgtools/pkglint which helps to check the contents of these files. After installation it is quite easy to use, just change to the directory of the package you wish to examine and execute pkglint:
Depending on the supplied command line arguments (see pkglint(1)) more verbose checks will be performed. Use e.g. pkglint -v for a very verbose check.

sect1.para: Everything seems OK, so install the files:
sect1.screen: &rprompt; make install >> Checksum OK for bison-1.25.tar.gz. ===> Installing for bison-1.25 sh ./mkinstalldirs /usr/pkg/bin /usr/pkg/share /usr/pkg/info /usr/pkg/man/man1 rm -f /usr/pkg/bin/bison cd /usr/pkg/share; rm -f bison.simple bison.hairy rm -f /usr/pkg/man/man1/bison.1 /usr/pkg/info/bison.info* install -c -o bin -g bin -m 555 bison /usr/pkg/bin/bison /usr/bin/install -c -o bin -g bin -m 644 bison.s1 /usr/pkg/share/bison.simple /usr/bin/install -c -o bin -g bin -m 644 ./bison.hairy /usr/pkg/share/bison.hairy cd .; for f in bison.info*; do /usr/bin/install -c -o bin -g bin -m 644 $f /usr/pkg/info/$f; done /usr/bin/install -c -o bin -g bin -m 644 ./bison.1 /usr/pkg/man/man1/bison.1 ===> Registering installation for bison-1.25
sect1.para: You can now use bison, and also - if you decide so - remove it with pkg_delete bison. Should you decide that you want a binary package, do this now:
